item.title: The Sylow Theorems
item.description: Statements & Proofs Let $G$ be a finite group. By Lagrange’s Theorem, every subgroup $H\substructeq G$ must have order dividing $|G|$. The converse is not necessarily true; that is, if $d$ divides $|G|$, there may not be a subgroup $H\substructeq G$ with order $d$. However, that $\Z$ is a UFD motivates us to write $|G|=p^rm$ for some prime $p$ not dividing $m$. item.title: Subgroup Products
item.description: Let $G$ be a group and consider subgroups $H,K\substructeq G$, whose subgroup product is $$\begin{equation} HK\coloneqq\l\{hk\in G\st h\in H,k\in K\r\}. \end{equation}$$ In general, this need not be a subgroup of $G$. Here, we give sufficient criteria in which this is the case. We also examine when $HK\nsubgrpeq G$ is a normal subgroup. Note, however, that even if $HK\not\substructeq G$, we have $|HK|=|H||K|/|H\cap K|$ if both $H$ and $K$ are finite.

item.title: Cauchy’s Theorem
item.description: Motivation & Statement Let $G$ be a finite group. By Lagrange’s Theorem, every subgroup $H\substructeq G$ must have order dividing $|G|$. The converse is not necessarily true; that is, if $d$ divides $|G|$, there may not be a subgroup $H\substructeq G$ with order $d$. Cauchy’s Theorem can be regarded as a partial converse thereof, stating that if $p$ is a prime divisor of $|G|$, then there is a ( cyclic) subgroup $H\substructeq G$ of order $p$.

item.title: Conjugation Action
item.description: Motivation & Definition One fundamental way that a group can act on itself is via conjugation, defined by $\phi_g(x)\coloneqq gxg^{-1}$ for all $g\in G$. item.title: The Class Equation
item.description: Statement & Proof A group $G$ acting on a finite set $S$ naturally partitions $S$ into its orbits $S=\bigsqcup_{i\in I}Gs_i$, which can either be trivial or non-trivial. The trivial ones are singletons $\l\{s_i\r\}$ for which each $s_i$ is fixed by all $g\in G$. We call those the fixed points of the action, denoted $Z\coloneqq\l\{s\in S\st gs=s\textrm{ for all }g\in G\r\}$. If some structure is known about the non-trivial orbits, then this partition gives us information on the number $\l|Z\r|$ of fixed points of this action.

item.title: Lagrange’s Theorem
item.description: Statement & Proof This classical result is fundamental in finite group theory, since it places limitations on the size a subgroup of a finite group can have. For a subgroup $H\substructeq G$ of $G$, let $[G:H]\coloneqq\l|G/H\r|$ be the index of $H$ in $G$. Theorem (Lagrange). Let $G$ be a finite group. For every subgroup $H\substructeq G$, we have $\l|G\r|=[G:H]\cdot\l|H\r|$. In particular, $\l|H\r|$ divides $\l|G\r|$. Proof. Click to expand... Consider the natural left-multiplication

item.title: Cayley’s Theorem
item.description: Motivation & Statement Whenever one encounters a type of mathematical object, one should ask if there is an associated ‘representation theorem’. Such a theorem for groups is as follows. Theorem (Cayley). Every group $G$ is a subgroup of a symmetry group. Proof. Click to expand... We show that the left-multiplication action $\phi:G\to\Aut G$ is faithful, for then $G\substructeq\Aut G$. Indeed, if $\phi(g_1)=\phi(g_2)$, then we have $\phi(g_1)g=\phi(g_2)g$ for all $g\in G$. That is, we have $g_1g=g_2g$, so $g_1=g_2$ as desired.

item.title: Quotient Group
item.description: Motivation & Definition Fix an equivalence relation on a group $G$ and consider the quotient set $G/\!\sim$. Since $\sim$ has, a priori, nothing to do with the group structure of $G$, we cannot expect $G/\!\sim$ to carry a natural group structure. Instead, we need to consider a congruence $\sim$ on $G$, which (in the category $\catgrp$) is an equivalence relation $\sim$ such that $g_1\sim g_2$ and $h_1\sim h_2$ implies $g_1h_1\sim g_2h_2$.

item.title: Normal Subgroup
item.description: Motivation & Definition Fix a group $G$ and consider the category $\cat{B}G$ defined by $G$ (consisting of a single object $\ast$, and morphisms $\Hom(\ast,\ast)=G$). What are the congruences in $\cat{B}G$? Definition. A subgroup $N\substructeq G$ is said to be normal if it is invariant under the conjugation action of $G$; i.e., if $gN=Ng$ for all $g\in G$. In this case, we write $N\nsubgrpeq G$, and $N\nsubgrp G$ if it is proper.

item.title: Kernel (Group Theory)
item.description: Motivation & Definition A special property of the category of groups is the existence of a zero object; namely, the trivial group $\l\{0\r\}$; by definition, we have a morphism $0:G\to\l\{0\r\}\to H$ for each pair $G,H$ of groups. Now, for an arbitrary homomorphism $f:G\to H$, we would like to find some group $K$ that ‘forces’ $f$ to ‘equalize’ with $0$ in a universal way. This can be done in two $-$ dual $-$ ways, called the kernel and cokernel of $f$.

item.title: Subgroup
item.description: Definition and Generation A standard method of studying an object $-$ in this case, a group $G$ $-$ is to analyze other groups that ‘sit inside’ $G$. This is formalized in the following Definition. Let $G$ be a group. A subgroup of $G$ is a subset $H\subseteq G$ equipped with a group structure making the inclusion $H\into G$ a group homomorphism. We write $H\substructeq G$ to indicate that $H$ is a subgroup of $G$.

item.title: Finite Group
item.description: Let $G$ be a group. The condition that (the underlying set of) $G$ is finite allows us to apply methods from finite combinatorics to analyze $G$. We give some group-theoretic frameworks for which such combinatorics can be applied to. Such methods can become incredibly sophisticated; for instance, the classification of finite simple groups is one of the major achievements of mathematics. We only touch on the very very basics here.

item.title: Free Group
item.description: Motivation & Definition Fix a set $X$. We would like to ‘canonically’ construct a group $F(X)$ containing $X$ ‘in the most efficient way’. The latter is encoded by a universal property, and the former makes $F:\catset\to\catgrp$ a left-adjoint to the forgetful functor $U:\catgrp\to\catset$. Definition. A free group on $X$ is a group $F(X)$ equipped with a function $j:X\to F(X)$ that is universal in the following sense: For every group $G$ and any function $f:X\to UG$, there is a unique group homomorphism $f’:F(X)\to G$ such that $Ff’\circ j=f$.

item.title: Integers
item.description: The set of integers $-$ denoted $\Z$ $-$ appear everywhere in algebra: In group theory, it is the free group on one generator, and is used to construct all cyclic groups, and more generally, all finitely-generated abelian groups. In ring theory, it is the initial object in $\catring$, and is the most important example of a PID. In fact, abelian groups are just $\Z$-modules. The fundamental property of $\Z$, and that underlies all of its group and ring-theoretic properties, is the Division Algorithm.

item.title: Order
item.description: Motivation & Definition Let $G$ be a group. The order of an element $x\in G$ is the size of its generated cyclic subgroup. A more elementary definition is as follows. Definition. An element $x\in G$ has finite order if $x^n=e$ for some $n>0$; the least such $n$ is the order of $x$, denoted $\ord x$. Otherwise, set $\ord x\coloneqq\infty$, and say that $x$ has infinite order. Proof ($\ord x=|\!\gen{x}|$). Click to expand.

item.title: Cyclic Group
item.description: Motivation & Definition The simplest class of groups are the cyclic groups, which are those that are generated by a single element. Definition. A group $G$ is said to be cyclic if $G=\gen{x}$ $^\dagger$ for some $x\in G$. Classification Let $G=\gen{x}$ be cyclic. By definition, $\phi:\Z\to G$ sending $m\mapsto x^m$ is surjective. Depending on the order $n\coloneqq\ord x$ of $x$, $G$ takes on the following forms. If $1\leq n<\infty$, then $\ker\phi=n\Z$ and hence $^\dagger$ $G\iso\Z/n\Z$.

item.title: Group Action
item.description: Motivation & Definition Groups capture $-$ abstractly $-$ the notion of a symmetry. But symmetries are also present in ‘concrete objects’, with different kinds of objects preserving different kinds of structure. The concept of a group action connects the two. Definition. Let $G$ be a group and fix a category $C$. A $G$-action is a functor $\cat{B}G\to C$, which specifies an object $X\in C$ and a homomorphism $\phi:G\to\Aut X$. Thus a group action is specified by the data of a tuple $\tpl{X,\phi}$, which we usually write as $\phi:G\act X$, and write $\phi_g(x)\coloneqq\phi(g)(x)$.

item.title: Abelian Group
item.description: Motivation & Definition Here, we consider a class of groups which $-$ despite being very general $-$ exhibit very useful properties absent in general groups. Definition. A group $G$ is said to be Abelian if $gh=hg$ for all $g,h\in G$. item.title: Group
item.description: Motivation & Definition The concept of a group was invented to capture the abstract properties of symmetries (i.e. transformations that preserve internal ‘structure’) of geometrical objects. These transformations must be composable in the following coherent way. Definition. A group is a tuple $\tpl{G,\cdot,e,\iota}$ consisting of underlying set $G$, a distinguished element $e\in G$ called the identity, and operations $\cdot:G\times G\to G$ and $\iota:G\to G$, subject to the following conditions. (Associativity). For all $g,h,k\in G$, we have $g\cdot(h\cdot k)=(g\cdot h)\cdot k$.
